column2: EASTL stands for Electronic Arts Standard Template Library.  It is an extensive and robust implementation that has an emphasis on high performance.

Fix memory leak in string_hash_map::insert_or_assign (#303)

* Fix memory leak in string_hash_map::insert_or_assign

Previous implementation always duplicated the key
(even if a previous key already existed).

A leak occurred because the clear was not aware of the
previous key that was discared by the newly duplicated key.

This solution only duplicates a new key if necessary.

Fix UB causing crashes with some compilers. (#280)

It's not allowed (Undefined Behavior) to call memmove with null pointers even if the size is 0.
In vector::DoInsertValueEnd memmove is called via eastl::uninitialized_move_ptr_if_noexcept unconditionally even for null pointers (when vector is empty).
Therefore, further checks for p in vector::DoFree and allocator::deallocate get optimized away which leads to crashes.

3.13.00 release

Fix an enumeral/non-enumeral type mix (#257)

With a recent gcc and -Wextra, compiling string.h yields a warning:

EASTL/string.h:3255:55: warning: enumeral and non-enumeral type in conditional expression [-Wextra]
   return (currentCapacity <= SSOLayout::SSO_CAPACITY) ? SSOLayout::SSO_CAPACITY : (2 * currentCapacity);

This patch fixes the warning by turning the enumeral into an explicit
size_type member variable

   return (currentCapacity <= SSOLayout::SSO_CAPACITY) ? SSOLayout::SSO_CAPACITY : (2 * currentCapacity);

hashtable: DoInsertKey with externally provided hash value (#244)

In some cases calculation a hash can be expensive and application can already have it calculated.
This doesn't change any public API functions, but allows external application to save some performance
by using already caclulated hash in their own hashmap/hashset implementation based on internal EASTL 'hashtable' container

Fixing bug in fixed_tuple_vector test case

* Make ctors in tuple conditionally explicit for init-list's of tuples

* Removed explicit constructions from init-lists in fixed_tuple_vector

* Improving support for conditionally-explicit constructors on tuple

Also fixing a couple compilation errors in TestFixedTupleVector
Adding test case for conditionally-explicit ctor

* Removing some bits from testing/iteration that were accidentally included

* Updates to init-list support for compressed_pair's

* Rework of "is_constructible" type_trait to use intrinsics where possible

This fixes an issue where some helper functions (for verifying some _other_ type traits) on ::tuple_vector or ::tuple would fail to construct on some aligned data types on VS2015. Gcc still uses the non-intrinsic variant.

Misc build fixes (#211)

* Add some missing includes

These caused build errors if EASTL/string_view.h was included before any
other files

* Fix build errors when compiling with EASTL_STRING_OPT_RANGE_ERRORS

basic_string::compare tried to access data members that no longer exist.

* Add support for compiling with clang-cl

clang-cl was previously identified as a Clang compiler, which was the
cause of some subtly incorrect behaviour.

1. A CMake script added GCC-style flags to a clang-cl command, which
triggered an unknown argument warning.

2. EABase was checking for clang-specific macros that aren't defined
in CL-mode; clang-cl is now treated as an MSVC compiler in the majority
of cases.

Fix unmached optional value constructor/destructor calls (#188)

Optional copy constructor should use inplace constructor
instead copy assigment operator because constructed value,
does not exist yet and assigment operator can not be used.

Optional move constructor should not use swap operation
for engaged flag because according to C++ draft N4762, page 537:
constexpr optional(optional&& rhs) noexcept(see below );
7 Effects: ... bool(rhs) is unchanged.
8 Ensures: bool(rhs) == bool(*this).

Optional assignment operators should use in-place construct
instead value assignment operator if lhs if nullopt.
If rhs is nullopt it should destruct value in lhs.

Also move assigment operator should not use
swap for engaged flag because according to C++ draft N4762, page 539:
optional<T>& operator=(optional&& rhs) noexcept(see below );
8 Effects: ... The result of the expression bool(rhs) remains unchanged.
10 Ensures: bool(rhs) == bool(*this).

Test where unique ptr moved from one to another optional is
incorrect due to after optional moved bool(optional) remains unchanged.
Test fixed and unique_ptr ownership movement check added.

* is_final

Updating the fixed_pool impl of swap to use Move  (#193)

And adding a corresponding test case in TestFixedVector to check this.

C++20: type_trait's endian (#196)

Improved the sorting tests (#191)

The first improvement is to add a sanity check to make sure the sum of the array elements is the same after sorting as before sorting.  Otherwise a sort function that simply zeroed every element in the container could pass the 'is_sorted' test.

The second improvement was to add a test that verifies if the stable sort algorithms are actually stable.

Merge tag '3.10.00'

3.10.00 Release
3.10.00 release

Added benchmarks for std::stable_sort. (#189)

The rationale for adding this is the same as for benchmarking std::sort.  Namely that there should be a benchmark against the std implementations of this sort to ensure the EASTL equivalent of std::stable_sort has competitive performance.

Made a couple radix sort optimizations (#179)

* Optimized radix_sort to reduce memory traffic and potentially skip some scatter operations depending on the input data being sorted.

This change also removes two specializations of radix_sort that can be handled by the generic code.
The change also introduces a template parameter for 'DigitBits' which defaults to 8.  In some cases users may be able to acheive even better performance by tuning this value based on the data being sorted.

* Added radix_sort tests including tests that exercise the internals of the optimized algorithm and test various values for 'DigitBits'.

Fix warnings (#186)

* Fix warnings

* use static assert

Adding tests and fixes for, e.g., comparison of tuples w/ non-const refs (#185)

"const" qualifier on const tuple_element_t<I, TupleImpl<Indices, Ts...>>& gets dropped when Ts is an lvalue ref. In this case, the only source of 'const-ness' on tuple_element_t comes from being baked into the source type. This means for non-const lvalue refs, the return type just bcomes "Ts&", but getInternal will attempt to return a const-ref values, and fail to compile because we cannot remove the const qualifier. Changing out the typename used by adding const specifically to the type of the ref, instead of trying to add it to the ref, solves the problem and we guarantee a const-ref return type.
Adding "bonus" headers to files included in EASTL project (#183)
Fix a few more _YVALS -> _CPPLIB_VER. (#184)

Adding test cases and fixes around move-only/ref types for Tuples (#181)

Additional test cases now check that tuples with move-only ref types now compile properly, instead of, apparently, finding a template deduction that attempted an implicit cast to value-type.

Also, the missing cast of a ValueType& for the TupleLeaf ref specialization was added to satisfy the new test cases.

Test for Dinkumware with _CPPLIB_VER instead of _YVALS. (#182)

In VS2017 "15.8" changes have been made to the standard library to allow
including some headers, like <type_traits>, in completely freestanding (not
linking with msvcp140.dll) mode, so that these may be consumed by the kernel
or similar constrained environments.

Unfortunately this causes problems because the link dependency on the DLL is
injected in yvals.h, so including <cstddef> no longer causes _YVALS to be
defined, since that is the header guard for the yvals.h header.

This file is already using _CPPLIB_VER for detection of specific Dinkumware
version, so it's already assuming _CPPLIB_VER indicates Dinkumware, and that
macro is at least pseudo-documented.

Fix constexpr specifier for integral_constant (#177)

integral_constant<T, v>::value should be constexpr.

This fix use of constexpr non-integral constants, e.g.:
type_traits.h:264:18: error: `constexpr` needed
for in-class initialization of static data member
`int* const eastl::integral_constant<int*, 0u>::value`
of non-integral type [-fpermissive]

Adding "inline" to a handful of get() functions for TupleImpl (#178)

The lack of inline on these functions was causing some performance problems in some situations where tuple is heavily utilized, often resulting in having to change Cmake's "RelWithDebugInfo" generated configuration in order to get accurate performance data. 
Note that both of these functions callers and callees have the inline tag, and when "any suitable" inlining is enabled, these functions get inlined away in almost all cases - after all, it just acts as an intermediary between TupleImpl and one of its TupleLeaf's.

Fixed a bug related to gVerbosityLevel. (#176)

The variable was previously declared as being static which meant it could take on different values in different translation units.  The issue was resolved by making the variable extern and defining it in EAEntryPointMain.inl (which is assumed to be included exactly once for a program).

Implemented basic command line handling in EAMain. (#175)

* Implemented basic command line handling in EAMain.

Note: Some constructors for the CommandLine class still have empty implementations.  However enough of the class has been implemented to be useful on Windows/Unix systems.

* Implemented a case sensitive/insensitive string prefix helper function to avoid depending on non-standard string compare functions.

The code used should be more portable than trying to detect what case insensitive compare function is available on each platform, and it also avoids dependencies on other libraries to provide this functionality.

Radix sort test improvements (#174)

* Implemented test verification for radix_sort which was previously not implemented.

This change also eliminates some redundancy defining the various RadixSortElement types.

Note: Tests for RadixSortElement8 now fail because of a bug in the uint8_t specialization for radix_sort_impl.

* Resolved a bug in the uint8_t specialization of radix_sort_impl that was detected by adding verification to a sorting test.

Radix sort benchmark improvements (#172)

* Added a new randomization type that is somewhat similar to kOrdered, but doesn't perform in a pathological way for radix_sort.

* Removed a bunch of special case code for radix sort benchmarks by implementing a custom key extractor.

* Added ability to benchmark radix_sort for the "slow assignment" tests.

Note: this change also modified the element being compared from a int32_t to a uint32_t so that the test could be easily performed using radix sort.

Allowed kSize[] to be updated without requiring manual updates to kSizeCount or kArraySizeMax. (#170)

Various sort benchmarks now operate on a vector of sort functions instead of explicitly skipping sort functions in multiple locations. This change also eliminates the need to handle sort functions in switch statements in order to skip them.

The primary reason for these changes is so that it is easier to benchmark larger array sizes and/or to modify the sort functions that will be benchmarked (since it quickly becomes impractical to benchmark O(n^2) sort functions for larger array sizes).

Rename IN to in, to avoid compiler errors on windows (#123)

Check for empty range in vector::erase(first,last) (#124)

* Check for empty range in vector::erase(first,last)

When erase() is called on a vector with an empty range (first == last),
it should be a no-op. If erase() does not check for this case, it can
end up calling the move assignment operator for an obect with itself as
the source and dest. This is unnecessary work at best, and at worst
could cause problems if the object's implementation of the move
assignment does not handle this case well, leaving the object in an
undefined state.

This fix simply adds a check for first==last and avoids doing any work
in that case.

* Update naming for empty vector::erase() test
